Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Mark Allen is "Free Boundaries on Manifolds with Singularities." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Texas at Austin, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Luis Caffarelli.

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas at Austin

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: While under this grant, the PI did research on free boundary problems and nonlocal differential equations. Free boundary problems arise when there is an interface or boundary between two areas and it is not known from the outset how the interface will move over time. The movement and shape of the interface is determined by mathematical equations that are determined by physical laws or experimental observation. The PI did research on how free boundaries interact with topological singularities. In one particular instance the PI considered when a free boundary is allowed to pass through the vertex of a cone. The PI also did research on nonlocal equations. In the physical sciences, phenomena often involve long range interactions. These longe range interactions are accounted for by using nonlocal or fractional derivatives. The PI also studies free boundary problems that arise in models involving nonlocal equations. 

 

Broader Impacts: While under this grant and because of the grant funding, the PI was able to help and mentor many younger researchers including those from historically underrepresented groups. Although the PI was not an official advisor to graduate students, the PI was available to advise graduate students on both research problems as well as entry into the academic community. This outreach was not limited to the host institution. Because of the funding made available through the grant, the PI was able to attend many conferences and reach out and help many younger researchers. 

 

Summary of outcomes: While under this grant, the PI was able to publish several articles. These include: Free boundaries on two-dimensional cones, The two-phase fractional obstacle problem, A parabolic problem with a fractional time derivative, Porous Medium Flow with both a fractional potential pressure and fractional time derivative. Also, the PI was able to do research which resulted in the following articles which have been either submitted for publication or accepted for publication: A Nondivergence Parabolic Problem with a Fractional Time Derivative,  Holder regularity for nondivergence nonlocal parabolic equations, A Fractional Free Boundary Problem related to a Plasma Problem. In addition, the PI was able to present these research outcomes at several conferences and institutions.
